G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: G.L. c. 208, § 28 authorizes the Probate and Family Court to revise and alter judgments concerning the care, custody, and maintenance of minor children as circumstances of the parents and the benefit of the children may require, upon a showing of a material and substantial change in circumstances and the child’s best interests.

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28A.proposition: This Court has continuing jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28; G.L. c. 208, § 28A; G.L. c. 209C, § 20, and the continuing jurisdiction principles described in G.L. c. 209B (Massachusetts Child Custody Jurisdiction Act), because Massachusetts entered the original custody judgment and the child and Mother remain residents of Massachusetts.

G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 20.proposition: This Court has continuing jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28; G.L. c. 208, § 28A; G.L. c. 209C, § 20, and the continuing jurisdiction principles described in G.L. c. 209B (Massachusetts Child Custody Jurisdiction Act), because Massachusetts entered the original custody judgment and the child and Mother remain residents of Massachusetts.

G.L. c. 209B.proposition: This Court has continuing jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28; G.L. c. 208, § 28A; G.L. c. 209C, § 20, and the continuing jurisdiction principles described in G.L. c. 209B (Massachusetts Child Custody Jurisdiction Act), because Massachusetts entered the original custody judgment and the child and Mother remain residents of Massachusetts.

G.L. c. 215, \u00a7 3.proposition: Venue is proper in the Middlesex Probate and Family Court pursuant to G.L. c. 215, § 3 and applicable venue rules, as the existing custody order was issued here and the child primarily resides within this Court’s jurisdiction.

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 31.proposition: G.L. c. 208, § 31 sets forth the standard that custody and parenting determinations are to be made in the best interests of the child, considering the child’s welfare, happiness, and development, as further articulated in *Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. at 842–44, and *Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. at 595–96.

*Schuh v. Schuh*, 94 Mass. App. Ct. 110.proposition: Since entry of the 2021 Judgment, there has been a material and substantial change in circumstances, warranting modification of the existing parenting-time schedule pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28 and relevant caselaw, including but not limited to *Schuh v. Schuh*, 94 Mass. App. Ct. 110 (2018); *Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006); *Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257 (2001); and *Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).
*Schuh v. Schuh*, 94 Mass. App. Ct. 110.case_name: Smaland Beach Association, Inc. v. Genova
*Schuh v. Schuh*, 94 Mass. App. Ct. 110.support_reasoning: This opinion is a real property/easement and derelict fee statute case about beach, road, and pond-front rights between neighboring landowners. It does not concern custody, parenting time, modification standards, or G.L. c. 208, § 28, nor does it discuss material and substantial changes in circumstances in a domestic relations context. Citing this case for a parenting-time modification standard is therefore inaccurate and unsupported by its holding or reasoning.
*Schuh v. Schuh*, 94 Mass. App. Ct. 110.relevant_excerpt: N/A – the opinion contains no discussion of G.L. c. 208, § 28, child custody, parenting time, or modification based on a material and substantial change in circumstances; it deals exclusively with property rights, easements, and adverse possession related to Crescent Road and the Smaland beach area.

*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).proposition: Since entry of the 2021 Judgment, there has been a material and substantial change in circumstances, warranting modification of the existing parenting-time schedule pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28 and relevant caselaw, including but not limited to *Schuh v. Schuh*, 94 Mass. App. Ct. 110 (2018); *Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006); *Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257 (2001); and *Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).
*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).support_reasoning: Mason v. Coleman is a removal/relocation case under G.L. c. 208, § 30, not a standard § 28 modification case based on a post‑judgment material and substantial change in circumstances. The Court discusses how to evaluate a proposed relocation in joint physical custody situations using a best‑interests analysis and cites ALI Principles (which themselves speak of relocation as a substantial change), but Mason does not hold that a material and substantial change has occurred or set out the § 28 modification standard. It therefore does not directly support the proposition that there has been a material and substantial change in circumstances warranting modification of a parenting-time schedule under § 28.
*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).relevant_excerpt:
“The Principles of the Law of Family Dissolution § 2.17 (2002)… state in pertinent part:
‘(1) The relocation of a parent constitutes a substantial change in circumstances… only when the relocation significantly impairs either parent’s ability to exercise responsibilities the parent has been exercising or attempting to exercise [under the judgement of divorce]…
(4)… If neither parent has been exercising a clear majority of custodial responsibility for the child, the court should modify the plan… in accordance with the child’s best interests…’”

*Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: Since entry of the 2021 Judgment, there has been a material and substantial change in circumstances, warranting modification of the existing parenting-time schedule pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28 and relevant caselaw, including but not limited to *Schuh v. Schuh*, 94 Mass. App. Ct. 110 (2018); *Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006); *Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257 (2001); and *Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).
*Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: This case interprets G.L. c. 208, § 28, but it does so to hold that the circumstances relied upon by the Probate Court (the mother’s relocation request and the court‑imposed temporary change in custody) did NOT constitute a material and substantial change justifying a modification of custody. The opinion therefore emphasizes that a modification requires a qualifying material and substantial change, and reverses a modification where such a change was lacking. It does not provide authority for the proposition that, in a later case, there *has* been a material and substantial change warranting modification.
*Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “Our decision today, that a request for modification of custody is distinct from a request to relocate and must be based on a material and substantial change in circumstances other than the move, is consistent with these decisions and with G. L. c. 208, § 28… A judgment modifying custody must be based on findings grounded in the evidence that, since the date of the prior custody order, there has been a change in circumstances ‘of sufficient magnitude….’ … There is nothing in the findings or the record before us to indicate that anything occurred after the divorce that so altered the circumstances of the parties as to warrant a change in custodial arrangements….”}

*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).proposition: Since entry of the 2021 Judgment, there has been a material and substantial change in circumstances, warranting modification of the existing parenting-time schedule pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28 and relevant caselaw, including but not limited to *Schuh v. Schuh*, 94 Mass. App. Ct. 110 (2018); *Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006); *Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257 (2001); and *Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).
*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).support_reasoning: Custody of Kali concerns an initial custody determination under G.L. c. 209C, § 10(a), not a post‑judgment modification under G.L. c. 208, § 28 (or c. 209C, § 20). The SJC explicitly declines to apply or discuss the ‘substantial change in circumstances’ standard and instead analyzes only the ‘best interests of the child’ standard and the statutory factors for first-time custody awards. Thus, while it is relevant to best‑interests analysis generally, it does not provide authority for the specific proposition that a material and substantial change in circumstances is required to modify an existing parenting-time schedule under § 28.
*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).relevant_excerpt: “We also decline to consider the father’s claim that the probate judge should have applied the ‘substantial change in the circumstances’ standard applicable to modification actions brought under G. L. c. 209C, § 20, rather than the ‘best interests of the child’ standard applicable to custody determinations under G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a). … It is clear from the record that the case in the Probate Court was tried under G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a), not G. L. c. 209C, § 20….”

Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. at 184\u2013.proposition: These changed travel demands and associated emotional consequences for the child materially affect the child’s daily routine, emotional well-being, and educational stability, and constitute a material and substantial change of circumstances under Massachusetts law.

Rosen v. Rosen, 90 Mass. App. Ct. 677 (2.raw_text: Rosen v. Rosen, 90 Mass. App. Ct. 677 (2016)
Rosen v. Rosen, 90 Mass. App. Ct. 677 (2.proposition: These changed travel demands and associated emotional consequences for the child materially affect the child’s daily routine, emotional well-being, and educational stability, and constitute a material and substantial change of circumstances under Massachusetts law.
Rosen v. Rosen, 90 Mass. App. Ct. 677 (2.support_reasoning: The opinion in Rosen v. Rosen concerns equitable credits against child support arrears and retroactive modification under G.L. c. 119A, § 13(a); it does not address relocation, changed travel demands, or their emotional/educational impact on a child. Nowhere does the court analyze what constitutes a material and substantial change of circumstances based on travel burdens or emotional consequences for the child. Thus it provides no authority for the claimed proposition about changed travel demands constituting a material and substantial change under Massachusetts law.
Rosen v. Rosen, 90 Mass. App. Ct. 677 (2.relevant_excerpt: Consistent with the views of other jurisdictions, we conclude that a judge is not foreclosed by G. L. c. 119A, § 13(a), from determining whether “compelling circumstances of an equitable nature” warrant the allowance of a credit for the payor’s fulfillment of his or her child support obligation “in a manner other than as directed by the original order” but which nevertheless accomplishes the maintenance of the child as envisioned by the original order.

Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.proposition: These changed travel demands and associated emotional consequences for the child materially affect the child’s daily routine, emotional well-being, and educational stability, and constitute a material and substantial change of circumstances under Massachusetts law.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.support_reasoning: Yannas is a removal case decided under G.L. c. 208, § 30, not a post‑judgment modification case interpreting what qualifies as a "material and substantial change of circumstances." The opinion discusses how relocation and its effects on the child figure into a best‑interests/removal analysis, but it never frames those impacts as satisfying a material-change standard under Massachusetts modification law. Using this case to support that specific proposition therefore overreads its holding and context.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.relevant_excerpt: “Cases involving removal of a child from the jurisdiction present difficult choices. Unless one is to apply a fixed but arbitrary rule, the issue can be resolved only on a case by case basis. The effect on the child of any removal is most important. An evaluation of the best interests of the child requires attention to whether the quality of the child’s life may be improved by the change … and the extent to which moving or not moving will affect the emotional, physical, or developmental needs of the child.”

*Murray v. Super*, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146.proposition: These changed travel demands and associated emotional consequences for the child materially affect the child’s daily routine, emotional well-being, and educational stability, and constitute a material and substantial change of circumstances under Massachusetts law.
*Murray v. Super*, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146.support_reasoning: The case is a removal and child-support modification decision; it does not analyze what constitutes a ‘material and substantial change of circumstances’ for custody based on changed travel demands or emotional consequences to a child. The only use of ‘material and substantial change’ is in the context of child support (the mother’s remarriage and new husband’s contributions), not in relation to children’s travel burdens or routine/educational stability. Thus, it does not establish that such travel-related impacts constitute a material and substantial change under Massachusetts law.
*Murray v. Super*, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146.relevant_excerpt: “In support of his complaint for modification, the father alleged as a material and substantial change of circumstances the mother’s remarriage. At the time of the modification trial, the judge found that the father’s income had modestly increased… and that the mother’s income remained at zero. The judge further found, however, that the mother now receives estimated contributions from her new husband… Based on those changes… the judge reduced the father’s child support obligation…”

*Adoption of Hugo*, 428 Mass. 219, 225\u.proposition: Because the child is now older, more involved in school and structured after-school activities, and more sensitive to disruptions in her routine and rest, the impact of the Defendant’s relocation and the long commute is substantially greater now than it would have been at earlier ages, reinforcing the existence of a material change in circumstances.
*Adoption of Hugo*, 428 Mass. 219, 225\u.support_reasoning: The opinion is an adoption/best‑interests decision that does not involve a relocation dispute, commuting burdens, or the effect of a child’s increased age on the impact of a move or long commute. Its discussion of age and developmental needs is about comparing two adoptive placements and weighing transition trauma versus long‑term developmental benefits, not about material change in circumstances due to relocation. Thus it does not provide authority for the specific proposition about greater present impact of relocation and commute as a material change.
*Adoption of Hugo*, 428 Mass. 219, 225\u.relevant_excerpt:
“He also credited her testimony that, as Hugo advances to the age of formal schooling, it will be important to minimize his developmental deficits so that he can interact with peers and teachers to optimize his continuing growth and development.

The judge concluded that, while Ms. L. is a caring and loving professional foster parent, she has no record of accomplishment similar to Ms. J.’s, which he determined is ‘critical’ to Hugo’s future. He ruled that the trauma of Hugo’s removal from Ms. L. was outweighed by the long-term benefits of moving him to a family better able to help him address his developmental challenges.”

Vilakazi v. Maxie, 371 Mass. 406 (1976).proposition: Any modification of a custody or parenting-time order in Massachusetts must serve the best interests of the child.
Vilakazi v. Maxie, 371 Mass. 406 (1976).support_reasoning: The opinion clearly affirms that the controlling standard in custody determinations is the welfare (best interests) of the child, citing earlier Massachusetts cases and endorsing that rule. However, it discusses the standard in the context of an initial or current custody award and the court’s discretion, and only briefly references modification statutes (G.L. c. 208, §§ 28, 30) without expressly stating that every modification must serve the child’s best interests. It thus supports the general best‑interests principle governing custody and its modification, though the linkage to “any modification” is somewhat indirect.
Vilakazi v. Maxie, 371 Mass. 406 (1976).relevant_excerpt: “In Hersey v. Hersey, 271 Mass. 545, 555 (1930), we stated the basic rule applicable in such cases as follows: ‘The governing principle by which the court must be guided in deciding the issues raised is the welfare of the child. That is so both as matter of law and as matter of humanity. Every public and private consideration establishes this as the dominating rule.’ … ‘In providing for the custody of a minor child, while the feelings and the wishes of the parents should not be disregarded, the happiness and the welfare of the child should be the controlling consideration.’”

Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590, 595\u2.proposition: In evaluating the best interests of the child, Massachusetts courts consider, inter alia, the child’s emotional, physical, and developmental needs; the child’s relationship with each parent; educational stability; and the practical impact of proposed parenting arrangements.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590, 595\u2.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses the best interests of the child mainly in terms of the impact of domestic violence, the child’s bond and preferences regarding each parent, and his school performance. It does not articulate a general standard listing emotional, physical, and developmental needs, the parent–child relationship, educational stability, and the practical impact of parenting arrangements as factors. The case is focused on requiring explicit findings about domestic violence rather than setting out a comprehensive best‑interests test, so it only partially and implicitly touches on some of the factors in the claimed proposition.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590, 595\u2.relevant_excerpt: "The judge was also moved by the fact that the boy appeared to be doing very well in his school work and that the father takes a great interest in his activities, meeting regularly with the boy’s teachers. ... Although the boy was described in testimony as ‘a really bright student,’ we note that the preference of an eleven-year-old is not given decisive weight, although it is a factor to be considered. ... It is well documented that witnessing domestic violence, as well as being one of its victims, has a profound impact on children. There are significant reported psychological problems in children who witness domestic violence, especially during important developmental stages."

Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540, 547\u2.proposition: The best-interests standard does not guarantee either parent a particular quantum of parenting time; rather, it demands a parenting schedule that maximizes the child’s welfare, stability, and healthy relationship with both parents.
Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540, 547\u2.support_reasoning: The concurrence focuses on statutory interpretation under the paternity statute and on the mother’s right to relocate as the sole legal parent before paternity is established. It does not discuss or articulate a general principle that the best-interests standard does not entitle either parent to a particular quantum of parenting time or that it must instead maximize the child’s welfare and relationships with both parents. The only ‘best interests’ discussion is about stability and preserving an existing satisfactory arrangement, not about allocating parenting time between two legal parents in general.
Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540, 547\u2.relevant_excerpt: “After paternity was established, the judge was obligated to take as a given that the mother and the child resided 400 miles apart from, and in another State than, the father, and to fashion custody and visitation orders pursuant to the three factors set out in G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a), again respecting and not disturbing the mother’s decision to relocate. See Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 843 (2003) (‘If the parenting arrangement in which a child has lived is satisfactory and is reasonably capable of preservation, it is ordinarily in the child’s best interests to maintain that arrangement…’).”}

Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..raw_text: Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 899 (1981)
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: Under Massachusetts law, where a material change in circumstances is shown and the requested modification promotes the best interests of the child, the Court has both the authority and the responsibility to modify custody and parenting-time provisions.
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion concerns the standards for making an initial custody award and emphasizes that the controlling criterion is the welfare/best interests of the child, with required findings on relevant factors. It does not discuss modification proceedings, material changes in circumstances, or the court’s authority/responsibility to modify existing custody or parenting-time orders. Accordingly, it supports the ‘best interests’ standard generally, but not the specific modification proposition stated.
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “In a proceeding involving custody of a child, ‘as matter of law and as matter of humanity’ ‘[t]he governing principle by which the court must be guided in deciding the issues raised is the welfare of the child’ (emphasis supplied)… This court will not sustain a custody award unless all relevant factors in determining the best interests of the child have been weighed. The weight ascribed to the respective factors is to be measured solely in terms of its effect on the welfare or well being of the child.”
